member.name: T:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.IRecordInputStream
member.summary: Interface for input streams that offer special handling of records.

member.name: P:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.IRecordInputStream.RecordOptions
member.summary: Gets the record options applied to this stream.
member.value: One or more of the values.

member.name: P:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.IRecordInputStream.StopReadingAtPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the position in the stream after which no data will be read.
member.value: The position after which method will not return any data. The default value is the length of the stream.

remarks.para: For a stream where is set to you can use this property to ensure that no data after the boundary is read if you only wish to read records up to the boundary.

On the Jumbo DFS, crossing a block boundary will cause a network connection to be established and data to be read from a different data server. If you are reading records from only a single block (as is often the case for Jumbo Jet tasks) this property can be used to ensure that no data from the next block will be read.

Setting this property to a value other than the stream length if is not set, or to a value that is not on a structural boundary can cause reading to halt in the middle of a record, and is therefore not recommended.

member.name: P:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.IRecordReader.HasRecords
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether there are records available on the data source that this reader is reading from.
member.value: if this instance has records available and is not waiting for input; otherwise, .

remarks.para: The property indicates if the record reader is waiting for an external source to provide it with data, or has data available from which it can read records immediately. If this property is , it indicates that the method will not block waiting for an external event (it may, however, still block waiting for IO).

For example, a multi-input record reader may use the property to indicate whether any inputs have been added yet. If this multi-input record reader is reading from a file channel, this could be used to determine if the reader is waiting for data to be shuffled or if it is available now.
If the property is , it is still safe to call , there is just no guarantee that the call will return immediately.
If the property is and is , then the property must become at some point, provided there are no error conditions.
If the property is , the next call to can still return . After has returned , the property will also be
When the property changes, the event will be raised.
For multi-input record readers, this property applies only to the current partition; if the current partition changes, the value of the property should be reset.

member.name: M:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.IRecordWriter.FinishWriting
member.summary: Informs the record writer that no further records will be written.

remarks.para: This method is intended for record writers that need to perform additional writing to finalize their output. In Jumbo Jet, this method will be called before the writer's metrics are collected so they can include these additional writes.

It is allowed to dispose any output streams or other objects related to the output when this method is called, as no more writes will occur after that point. However, the and properties must still return the correct values after has been called.
The implementation for will call this method.

member.name: T:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.IValueWriter`1
member.summary: Interface for binary serialization of types that don't support .

remarks.para: Jumbo provides its own simple, light-weight serialization protocol that is primarily used by the and classes (although it is also used in a few other places).

Normally, classes support this protocol by implementing the interface. However, the interface cannot be used on value types (structs) because of the semantics of calling interface methods that modify the object's state on a value type.

To provide serialization support for a value type, you must create a class implementing for that value type, and mark the value type with the . Although you can use for reference types as well, this is not recommended because doesn't support record reuse.
Jumbo also provides implementations for several built-in framework types.
To access the implementation for a type, use the class.

member.name: T:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.IWritable
member.summary: Interface for objects that can be serialized using the and classes.

remarks.para: The interface provides a simple, light-weight serialization protocol that is used primarily by the and class (but is also used in a few other instances).

Unlike the serialization provided by the class, serialization is done entirely by the class that implements the interface. There are no built-in checks to see if the type being deserialized from a stream matches the type that was serialized to it. It is up to the implementation of the and methods to guarantee binary compatibility.

For this reason, it is recommended to use serialization only for short-time storage where the performance of serializing and deserializing is important. Its primary usage in Jumbo (intermediate data for Jumbo Jet jobs) fits these criteria.
Types that implement must be reference types (classes). To support serialization of value types, you must implement a for those types and mark them with the .

The creates new record instances by using the method. This means the object's constructors are not invoked, so the implementation may not make any assumptions about the state of the class, and must guarantee the object is in a consistent state after it finishes.

When record reuse is enabled, the method will be called multiple times on the same instance. The method must replace the entire internal state of the object with that of the new record. If any of the object's internal state is stored in reference types, it's recommended to reuse object instances as much as possible.

remarks.para: The reader will start reading at . If is larger than zero, the reader will seek ahead to the start of the next record and read from there.
The reader will read a whole number of records until the start of the next record falls after + . Because of this, the reader can read more than bytes.

The reader will check if implements with set to . If so, if falls on a structural boundary the reader will not seek ahead because it knows structural boundaries are record boundaries; if + falls on a structural boundary, the reader is guaranteed to not read beyond + .

remarks.para: Depending on the type of record reader, the records of the input record readers might not need to read records of type .
If you accept inputs of types other than , you must specify that using the .

member.summary: This class provides helper stuff for record files.

member.name: T:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.RecordFileHeader
member.summary: Represents the header of a record file.

remarks.para: A record file is a plain file containing a sequence of records, with an occasional record marker to make it possible to start reading at any point in the file and find the next record marker so you can start reading from the beginning of a record.
Record markers are 16 bytes random values created with the cryptographic for maximum entropy.
A record file begins with a header, which uses the following format:

item.description: Three bytes containing the ASCII string "REC", followed by a single byte containing the version number of the record file format.
The assembly qualified name of the type of the records, as a utf-8 encoded string, preceded by the string length (this is the format used by .
A 16-byte value specifying the record marker for this file.

remarks.para: After the header, a sequence of records follows. Each record is preceded by a 4 byte record prefix which is an integer in little endian format. If this prefix is -1, it is followed by a record marker, and not a record. Otherwise the prefix is followed by a record, which will be read by the record types implementation.
In future versions, the record prefix may be used for other information (such as the record size), but currently it will always be either -1 to indicate a record marker, or 0 to indicate a record.

to use the strong name of the assembly (if it has one) in the header; to use the simple name.

member.name: P:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.RecordReader`1.HasRecords
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether there are records available on the data source that this reader is reading from.
member.value: if this instance has records available and is not waiting for input; otherwise, .

remarks.para: The property indicates if the record reader is waiting for an external source to provide it with data, or has data available from which it can read records immediately. If this property is , it indicates that the method will not block waiting for an external event (it may, however, still block waiting for IO).

For example, a multi-input record reader may use the property to indicate whether any inputs have been added yet. If this multi-input record reader is reading from a file channel, this could be used to determine if the reader is waiting for data to be shuffled or if it is available now.
If the property is , it is still safe to call , there is just no guarantee that the call will return immediately.
If the property is and is , then the property must become at some point, provided there are no error conditions.
If the property is , the next call to can still return . After has returned , the property will also be
When the property changes, the event will be raised.
For multi-input record readers, this property applies only to the current partition; if the current partition changes, the value of the property should be reset.
This is a default implementation for that simply always returns until a call to has returned .

member.name: M:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.RecordWriter`1.FinishWriting
member.summary: Informs the record writer that no further records will be written.

remarks.note: Overriders must call the base class implementation to ensure the property gets set.
remarks.para: This method is intended for record writers that need to perform additional writing to finalize their output. In Jumbo Jet, this method will be called before the writer's metrics are collected so they can include these additional writes.

It is allowed to dispose any output streams or other objects related to the output when this method is called, as no more writes will occur after that point. However, the and properties must still return the correct values after has been called.
The implementation for will call this method. It is recommended to make it safe to call this method multiple times.

member.typeparam: The type of the records to read.

remarks.para: Deriving classes should start reading at . If is not on a record boundary, they should seek ahead to the first record boundary and start from there.
Deriving classes should use and to determine when to stop returning records. If + is not on a record boundary, they should continue reading until the next record boundary.

If the stream implements with set, and + is on a structural boundary, will be set to + . In this situation, may return 0 before bytes are read. A deriving class should check this and stop reading at that point.

member.name: T:Ookii.Jumbo.IO.ValueWriter`1
member.summary: Provides access to implementations for various basic framework types and types that specify the attribute.
member.typeparam: The type of the object whose or implementation to use.

remarks.para: If you attempt to access this class for a type that does not implement and that does not have a implementation of , an is thrown by the static type initializer of the class.
Built-in value writers are provided for the following types: , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , and .

Although value writers support tuples, there may be negative performance implications from using them. All the .Net Framework tuple types are reference types, but they are read-only and therefore do not support record reuse. This means that for every record, a new tuple object must be created, as well as new instances of any of the tuple's items that are reference types, even in situations where record reuse is allowed.
Instead of using tuples, it is recommended to create a custom class that implements for your records.
The structure is not supported by the value writer. Please use the class instead, which provides additional functionality for key/value pairs required by Jumbo.

member.summary: Abstract base class for writable types that provides a default implementation of based on reflection and code generation.
member.typeparam: The type of the writable type; this should be the type inheriting from .

remarks.para: The generated implementation will serialize all properties of the type. Because types may be created uninitialized (without calling the constructor), you must be sure it's safe to deserialize a type by simply setting all its properties, even if the constructor hasn't been run.
Because the serializer and deserializer are generated from the type , it is not safe to derive other classes from that type unless you override the and implementations.

member.summary: Uses reflection to creates a function that serializes an object to a ; this function can be used in a method.
member.typeparam: The type of the object to serialize.
member.returns: A delegate to a method that serializes the object.

remarks.para: The serializer created by this method will serialize only the public properties of the type which have a public get and set method. If you need to serialize additional state, you should do that manually.

The serializer supports properties that have a type supported by one of the overloads of the method, as well those who implement themselves. The serializer supports values by writing a before each property that has a reference type that indicates whether it's or not.

member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of elements the internal data structure can hold without resizing.
member.value: The number of elements that the can contain before resizing is required.

remarks.para: is the number of elements that the can store before resizing is required, while is the number of elements that are actually in the .

is always greater than or equal to . If exceeds while adding elements, the capacity is increased by automatically reallocating the internal array before copying the old elements and adding the new elements.

The capacity can be decreased by setting the property explicitly. When the value of is set explicitly, the internal array is also reallocated to accommodate the specified capacity, and all the elements are copied.

member.name: M:Ookii.Jumbo.PriorityQueue`1.Enqueue(`0)
member.summary: Adds an object to the .
member.param: The object to add to the queue. The value can be for reference types.

remarks.para: accepts as a valid value for reference types and allows duplicate elements.

The new element's position is determined by the implementation used to compare elements. If the new element is smaller than the current first element in the , the new element will become the first element in the queue. Otherwise, the existing first element will remain the first element.
If already equals , the capacity of the is increased by automatically reallocating the internal array, and the existing elements are copied to the new array before the new element is added.
If is less than , this method is an O(log n) operation, where n is . If the capacity needs to be increased to accommodate the new element, this method becomes an O(n log n) operation, where n is .

member.name: M:Ookii.Jumbo.PriorityQueue`1.AdjustFirstItem
member.summary: Indicates that the current first item of the was modified and its priority has to be re-evaluated.

remarks.para: If is a reference type and not immutable, it may be possible to modify the value of items in the queue. In general, this is not allowed and doing this will break the priority queue and lead to undefined behaviour.

However, it is allowed to modify the current first element in the queue (which is returned by ) if this change is followed by an immediate call to which re-evaluates the item's value and moves a different item to the front if necessary.

In the scenario that you are removing an item from the and immediately replacing it with a new one, using this function can yield better performance, as the sequence of , modify, is twice as slow as doing , modify, .
Because the first element may change after calling , it is not safe to continue modifying that same element afterwards. You must call again to get the new front element which may now be changed.
This method is an O(log n) operation, where n is .

member.name: M:Ookii.Jumbo.PriorityQueue`1.Clear
member.summary: Removes all objects from the .

remarks.para: is set to zero, and references to other objects from elements of the collection are also released.
The capacity remains unchanged. To reset the capacity of the , call . Trimming an empty sets the capacity of the to the default capacity.
This method is an O(n) operation, where n is .

member.name: M:Ookii.Jumbo.PriorityQueue`1.TrimExcess
member.summary: Sets the capacity to the actual number of elements in the , if that number is less than a threshold value.

remarks.para: This method can be used to minimize a collection's memory overhead if no new elements will be added to the collection. The cost of reallocating and copying a large can be considerable, however, so the method does nothing if the list is at more than 90 percent of capacity. This avoids incurring a large reallocation cost for a relatively small gain.
remarks.note: The current threshold of 90 percent it depends on and might change in future releases of the .Net Framework.
remarks.para: This method is an O(n) operation, where n is .
To reset a to its initial state, call the method before calling the method. Trimming an empty sets the capacity of the to the default capacity.
The capacity can also be set using the property.

member.param: The local IP address that the server should bind to.
The port to listen on.
The maximum number of simultaneous connections that the server will allow, or zero to have no maximum.

remarks.para: If is larger than zero, the class will maintain a count of connected clients on all specified end points. If a client tries to connect when the count is equal to , the connection will be refused.

If is larger than zero, the will send a 4-byte value (to keep the remaining data word-aligned) that is zero to indicate the connection was rejected, or non-zero to indicate it was accepted. When is zero, this value is not sent.

member.name: T:Ookii.Jumbo.Topology.RangeExpression
member.summary: Provides simple numeric range-based string matching.

remarks.para: The class allows you to match strings containing ranges of numbers.

String matching is done using a pattern. This pattern, in addition to regular text, can contain numeric ranges of the form "[n-m]" where n and m are both numbers, e.g. "[001-299]". The ranges are inclusive.
The number of characters in the upper bound determines the maximum number of characters; e.g. the expression "foo[1-099] matches "foo050" and "foo50" but not "foo0050".
In addition to ranges, you can also use alternation with the | character. For example, "foo[00-50]|bar[51-99]" will match both e.g. "foo25" and "bar75".
You can also group subexpressions in parentheses for use with alternation. For example "(foo|bar)[00-50]" will match both e.g. "foo25" and "bar25".

member.name: T:Ookii.Jumbo.UnmanagedBuffer
member.summary: Represents a buffer of memory stored on the unmanaged (native) heap.

remarks.para: This class is used as an alternative for byte[]. The main differences are that the memory is returned to the OS when the class is disposed/finalized, and the buffer is not zero-initialized.

The main reason for the existence of this class is Mono's reluctance to release memory from the managed heap back to the OS which can lead to pagefile thrashing if you're dealing with many large buffers. This problem may not apply to the sgen garbage collector, but this has not been tested.
